variant.question:
Aircraft sprayed with TYPE I Fluid, snow showers,
OAT=-3°C, Aircraft exceeds holdover time by 2 minutes
What should the commander do

options.text: Return to the deicing area and perform another deicing/anti-icing fluid
Turn on anti ice on the aircraft - this allows an additional 10 minutes hold over time
Continue flight
The pilot can make a judgment call, if the ice does not appear threatening he can take off

variant.question: Your aircraft has been de-iced and anti-ice fluid has been applied. Your actions as Commander of this aircraft will be to

options.text: Inform ATC, return to the stand and have the aircraft de-iced and new anti-ice fluid applied
Add 10 Knots to your VR speed to remove any icing before lift off
Continue with the take-off as you have already been cleared for take-off
Take off, and return to the aerodrome for deicing

take off speeds should be increased
As the temperature is below -10°, no precautions are required

angle of attack should be checked to ensure that they are clear of ice

The first step of a two-step procedure by which frost, ice, snow or slush is removed from an aircraft in order to provide uncontaminated surfaces.

variant.question: Choose the operational scenario that indicates understanding of the "Clean Aircraft Concept" with respect to aircraft de / anti-icing operations as determined by ICAO.

options.text: After completion of ground de / anti-icing, the Pilot in Command requests a close-up visual inspection of the horizontal stabiliser upper surface, which is not visible from the ground.
During ground operations with slush / snow present, the aircraft's flaps / slats should remain retracted / closed, preventing deposition of slush or snow and avoiding the need to de-ice the aircraft.

On the aircraft horizontal surfaces an even layer of dry powder is present. The powder snow can be brushed off. When there is no precipitation, the Pilot in Command can decide to increase take-off speed, to clear the aircraft of snow during the take-off run.
After completion of ground de / anti-icing with Type II or Type IV fluid, the aircraft is required to be cleaned of any residual fluid in an aerodynamically quiet area before the next flight.

The Commander should reject the aircraft and ask for an independant check by another aircraft engineer.
